One early approach, suggested by Kay (1987) and later pursued in different variants by Kiraz (1994, 2000) among others, was to, instead of modeling morphology along the more traditional finite-state transducer, modeling it with a n-tape automaton, where tapes would carry precisely this interleaving 1Following auto segmental analyses, this paper assumes the model where the vocalization is not merged with the pat tern ,i.e. we do not list separate patterns for vocalizations such as CaCaC as is assumed more traditionally
clean_text: One early approach, suggested by Kay (1987) and later pursued in different variants by Kiraz (1994, 2000) among others, was to, instead of modeling morphology along the more traditional finite-state transducer, modeling it with a n-tape automaton, where tapes would carry precisely this interleaving that is called for in Semitic interdigitation.

raw_text: Kay (1987) devised a framework with which each of the auto segmental tiers is assigned a tape in a multi-tape finite state machine, with an additional tape for the surface form
